meanings.definition: To cause someone to be no longer close or affectionate with someone else.
meanings.sent1: The argument between the friends began to estrange them from each other.
meanings.sent2: The misunderstanding started to estrange the siblings from each other.
meanings.sent3: The silly prank did not estrange the friends, but it did cause a temporary rift.
meanings.sent4: The harsh words spoken in anger seemed to estrange the once close friends.
meanings.sent5: The betrayal was so deep that it estranged the two friends forever.

meanings.definition: To make someone feel isolated or alienated.
meanings.sent1: The new student felt estranged in the unfamiliar school environment.
meanings.sent2: The constant teasing began to estrange the child from his classmates.
meanings.sent3: The strange costume made him feel estranged at the costume party.
meanings.sent4: The language barrier seemed to estrange him from the rest of the group.
meanings.sent5: The eerie silence of the abandoned house made her feel estranged from reality.

meanings.definition: To remove or keep at a distance.
meanings.sent1: The guard dog was trained to estrange strangers from the property.
meanings.sent2: The high fence was meant to estrange the curious neighbors from peering in.
meanings.sent3: The scarecrow was placed in the field to estrange the pesky birds.
meanings.sent4: The warning signs were there to estrange trespassers from entering the restricted area.
meanings.sent5: The moat around the castle was designed to estrange any potential invaders.
